docs.snippet: Nasty with unpredictability and generally greeted with both horror and delight, the sardine-packed Stargazy Pie, not unlike Owen Wilson and Wes Anderson's ''Royal Tenenbaums,'' is a spectacular, witty surprise and guarantees to kindle conversation...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nasty with unpredictability and generally greeted with both horror and delight, the sardine-packed Stargazy Pie, not unlike Owen Wilson and Wes Anderson's ''Royal Tenenbaums,'' is a spectacular, witty surprise and guarantees to kindle conversation at your next dinner party. Academy voters take note. According to the tough British food writer Jane Grigson, Stargazy pie (sometimes spelled ''Stargazey'') is a Cornish creation traditionally made on Tom Bawcock's Eve, two days before Christmas, commemorating the night on which brave Bawcock went to sea to find sustenance for his foodless hometown of Mousehole. Against all odds he returned with netfuls of sardines, fed the town with this pie and wound up with a dish and an extremely minor holiday named after him. Asking where the townspeople found the bacon and hard-boiled eggs in the foodless burg is as irrelevant as questioning how the girl who married Cain got there.
docs.abstract: Jonathan Reynolds cooking article on preparing sardine dishes, including Stargazy pie, Cornish creation; recipes; photo (M)

docs.snippet: HERE'S an ''Oklahoma!'' story: shortly before rehearsals began, one of the show's producers, Theresa Helburn, told the librettist Oscar Hammerstein II that he and the composer Richard Rodgers ought to write ''a song about the earth.''    Bewildere...
docs.lead_paragraph: HERE'S an ''Oklahoma!'' story: shortly before rehearsals began, one of the show's producers, Theresa Helburn, told the librettist Oscar Hammerstein II that he and the composer Richard Rodgers ought to write ''a song about the earth.'' Bewildered, Hammerstein asked Helburn what she meant.
docs.abstract: Ethan Mordden article on revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein musical Oklahoma!, set to open on Broadway on March 21, almost exactly 59 years since its premiere; revival, at Gershwin Theater, is directed by Trevor Nunn and choreographed by Susan Stroman; drawing; photo (M)

headline.main: Six Decades Later, Still The Great American Musical

docs.snippet: Is a poetic, ballet-influenced free-skating routine better than an athletic, entertainment-oriented one, even when the first is marred by a stumble coming out of a double axel and the second is technically perfect? Is this miniature poodle truly a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Is a poetic, ballet-influenced free-skating routine better than an athletic, entertainment-oriented one, even when the first is marred by a stumble coming out of a double axel and the second is technically perfect? Is this miniature poodle truly a more ideal specimen of its breed than that Kerry blue terrier? Is Russell Crowe's portrayal of the mathematician John Nash in ''A Beautiful Mind'' a ''powerful,'' Oscar-worthy performance or an irritating display of actorly ''mannerism''? There may be a preponderance of opinion on one side or the other of these questions, but each is fundamentally unanswerable -- which may explain why we just can't stop talking about them, especially when the official judgment conflicts with our own. Human beings have a yen for hierarchies; even if the most important aspects of our lives don't easily lend themselves to ranking, we feel compelled to try it anyway. Occasionally, deciding who's on top is easy enough: the New England Patriots indisputably if surprisingly won Super Bowl XXXVI, for example. Some contests, however, can be determined only through a process of subjective judging. For the empirically inclined, such competitions can be supremely irritating, but the popularity of figure skating, which dwarfs that of the Winter Olympics' more quantifiable events, suggests that these malcontents are in the minority.
docs.abstract: Laura Miller article on contests and awards that can be determine only through process of subjective judging; cites public delight in complaining about collective expert judges; photo (M)

docs.snippet: BRENDAN BEHAN made his name twice, first as a writer and then as a character. Raw talent cemented his status as the former; the bottle was a major factor in the latter.    He is probably the only modern playwright to have regularly heckled his own...
docs.lead_paragraph: BRENDAN BEHAN made his name twice, first as a writer and then as a character. Raw talent cemented his status as the former; the bottle was a major factor in the latter. He is probably the only modern playwright to have regularly heckled his own plays. On Broadway in the 1960's, he would interrupt performances of his work, drunkenly shouting from his seat and demanding in unprintable terms that the actors do the play the way he wrote it. His tipsy tirades during the run of ''The Hostage'' in 1960 became a bonus attraction: theatergoers arrived each night hoping as much to hear Behan's diatribe as Behan's dialogue.
docs.abstract: Peter Marks article on Borstal Boy, film about early life of Irish writer Brendan Behan directed by Irish writer and filmmaker Peter Sheridan and starring Michael York and Shawn Hatosy; photo (M)

headline.main: Film; A Portrait of the Artist As a Young Man in Jail

docs.snippet: IN ''Reading Lyrics,'' an anthology published in 2000, Robert Gottlieb and Robert Kimball compiled the texts of their thousand favorite songs written from 1900 to 1975. Essential reading for anyone interested in American popular song, this estimab...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN ''Reading Lyrics,'' an anthology published in 2000, Robert Gottlieb and Robert Kimball compiled the texts of their thousand favorite songs written from 1900 to 1975. Essential reading for anyone interested in American popular song, this estimable collection provides fascinating insights. It demonstrates, for example, how in the opening decades of the 20th century the popular song broke away from the traditions of operetta. Of the 109 lyricists or collaborating teams here, the ones most often cited are predictable: Irving Berlin comes in first with 39 lyrics, Cole Porter and Lorenz Hart tie with 37, and Ira Gershwin gets 35. But it may surprise many to find Pelham Grenville Wodehouse (known to his readers as P. G. Wodehouse and to his friends as Plum) represented by a respectable 11 lyrics.
docs.abstract: Johanna Keller article on P G Wodehouse's largely overlooked albeit successful career as songwriter, particularly his collaborations with Broadway musical composers Jerome Kern and Guy Bolton; Hunter College's Kaye Playhouse will present P G's Other Profession, evening of songs with Wodehouse lyrics, during New York Festival of Song; photos (M)

headline.main: Music; Words to Express the Extraordinary

docs.snippet: IT'S nice to see Hugh Grant playing a handsome cad (rather than a handsome ingenue) in BRIDGET JONES'S DIARY (2001), directed by Sharon Maguire and based on Helen Fielding's best seller. And it's more fun than ice cream to watch that cad and Colin...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S nice to see Hugh Grant playing a handsome cad (rather than a handsome ingenue) in BRIDGET JONES'S DIARY (2001), directed by Sharon Maguire and based on Helen Fielding's best seller. And it's more fun than ice cream to watch that cad and Colin Firth's character duke it out on the streets of London, crashing into a restaurant and pausing to say ''I'm so sorry'' whenever they knock something over. But the movie belongs to Renee Zellweger as Bridget, a 32-year-old single Briton who sets out to improve herself (lose weight, reduce alcohol and tobacco intake, etc.) and find love. All those smug married couples don't help -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:15 a.m. on Starz.

docs.snippet: DURDIN-Margaret (Peggy). Age 92, of pneumonia on February 12, 2002, at Silverado Senior Living, Encinitas, California. Beloved wife of the late F. Tillman Durdin, loving sister of Maude Hudson and Lena Albright, both deceased, and of brother Oscar...
docs.lead_paragraph: DURDIN-Margaret (Peggy). Age 92, of pneumonia on February 12, 2002, at Silverado Senior Living, Encinitas, California. Beloved wife of the late F. Tillman Durdin, loving sister of Maude Hudson and Lena Albright, both deceased, and of brother Oscar V. Armstrong of Mitchellville, MD, & of informally ''adopted'' son Edward Chen of Hong Kong. Born in China of missionary parents, she spent many years in Asia, accompanying her husband, a New York Times correspondent and writing feature articles for various American publications. She also served as an assistant to the editor of the New York Times Magazine.

docs.snippet: THE first time Nicole Kidman saw ''The Shining,'' she was 14 and spent most of the movie paying more attention to her 16-year-old boyfriend than to what was happening on the screen. ''I was meant to be going roller-skating at this rink in Sydney,'...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE first time Nicole Kidman saw ''The Shining,'' she was 14 and spent most of the movie paying more attention to her 16-year-old boyfriend than to what was happening on the screen. ''I was meant to be going roller-skating at this rink in Sydney,'' she said. ''But we decided to ditch that and go see a movie. I really wasn't supposed to be in there. I was too young, as I recall, but he got me in. I looked older. And I kind of watched a bit of the movie, but really, I made out through most of it.'' Later, she watched it again. By this time, she was a film actress herself. She and her husband at the time, Tom Cruise, had rented a huge, ancient chateau in France and were staying there all alone. So they decided to rent this 1980 film, which also takes place in a big, remote, nearly empty building, and late at night they slipped it into the VCR. ''We purposely watched it that way, to magnify the experience,'' Ms. Kidman said. ''It was terrifying.''
docs.abstract: Article in series Watching Movies With... presents actress Nicole Kidman's views on Stanley Kubrick's 1980 movie The Shining; Kidman also comments on working with Kubrick on 1999 film Eyes Wide Shut; photos (L)

headline.main: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Nicole Kidman; A Perfectionist's Pupil With a Major in Creepy

docs.snippet: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet. ''Moulin Rouge'' has been around on videocassette and DVD since December, and none of the other best-picture nominees are coming anytime soon. Only ''Gosford P...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet. ''Moulin Rouge'' has been around on videocassette and DVD since December, and none of the other best-picture nominees are coming anytime soon. Only ''Gosford Park'' has a release date scheduled: May 28. ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring,'' the candidate with the clumsiest title and most nominations (13), ''A Beautiful Mind'' and ''In the Bedroom'' should be along in the summer or fall. ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone,'' with three nominations, is scheduled for May 28 on VHS and DVD. The disc will have a footlong list of extras. Add cassette sales and the movie could be the biggest video ever.
docs.abstract: Home Video column on Oscar-nominated movies that have already been released in cassette and DVD form and others that will be released in March (M)

docs.snippet: Kevin Smith, who played the god of war in the ''Xena'' television series, died of head injuries last Friday in a hospital here, said a doctor. He was 38.     The New Zealand Herald reported that Mr. Smith fell from a great height, possibly six sto...
docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Smith, who played the god of war in the ''Xena'' television series, died of head injuries last Friday in a hospital here, said a doctor. He was 38. The New Zealand Herald reported that Mr. Smith fell from a great height, possibly six stories. He was in China to film a martial arts film, but the newspaper said that he was not on the movie set when he fell.
docs.abstract: Kevin Smith, who played god of war in Xena television series, dies of head injuries after a fall, Beijing, at age 38; photo (S)

headline.main: Kevin Smith, 38, Actor in 'Xena' TV Series
